variable_scoping.title: Variable Scoping and SHARED Variables
variable_scoping.description: QB64PE variable scoping rules and how to properly share variables between procedures

local_scope.description: Variables declared in SUB/FUNCTION are local by default
rules: Variables declared with DIM inside SUB/FUNCTION are local to that procedure
Local variables cannot be accessed from other procedures
Local variables are automatically destroyed when procedure exits
Parameters passed to SUB/FUNCTION are local to that procedure

global_scope.description: Variables declared in main program are global by default
rules: Variables declared in main program (outside SUB/FUNCTION) are global
Global variables can be accessed from any procedure using SHARED
Global variables persist throughout program execution

shared_variables.description: SHARED keyword allows procedures to access global variables
syntax: SHARED variableName  ' Reference existing global variable
rules: DIM SHARED creates a new global variable accessible from all procedures
SHARED (without DIM) references an existing global variable
SHARED must be declared at the beginning of each procedure that needs access
Arrays declared with DIM SHARED are global and accessible from all procedures

variable_not_in_scope.problem: Attempting to access variables from SUB/FUNCTION without proper scoping
solutions: Use DIM SHARED for variables that need global access

missing_shared_declaration.problem: Global variables not accessible in procedures

example.correct: SUB MyProc\n    SHARED globalVar\n    globalVar = 10  ' Now accessible

array_scope_issues.problem: Arrays not properly shared between procedures

example.incorrect: DIM myArray(100) AS INTEGER  ' Local to main\nCALL ProcessArray  ' Array not accessible in SUB
example.correct: DIM SHARED myArray(100) AS INTEGER  ' Global access\nCALL ProcessArray  ' Array accessible in SUB

dynamic_arrays.title: Dynamic Array Management
dynamic_arrays.description: QB64PE supports dynamic arrays with proper directives

directive.purpose: Allows arrays to be resized at runtime using REDIM
directive.placement: Must be placed before any array declarations that will be resized

characteristics: Size can be changed at runtime
syntax: DIM arrayName() AS dataType  ' Empty parentheses
REDIM arrayName(newSize) AS dataType  ' Resize as needed

best_practices: Use static arrays when size is known and fixed
Use dynamic arrays when size varies based on input or conditions
Place $DYNAMIC directive before first dynamic array declaration
Use REDIM PRESERVE to keep existing data when resizing
Be mindful of memory usage with large dynamic arrays

array_resizing.title: Array Resizing and Boundary Management
array_resizing.description: Comprehensive guide to resizing arrays and managing array boundaries safely

behavior: Destroys existing array contents
Allocates new memory with specified size
Can only be used with arrays declared with empty dimensions DIM arrayName()
Requires $DYNAMIC directive to be in effect
Can resize multiple dimensions: REDIM array(x, y, z)
limitations: Cannot change the number of dimensions
All existing data is lost unless using PRESERVE

REDIM_PRESERVE.purpose: Resize arrays while preserving existing data
behavior: Keeps existing data that fits in new size
Only allows changing the last dimension in multi-dimensional arrays
Data beyond new boundaries is lost if shrinking
New elements are initialized to zero/empty string
limitations: Slower than regular REDIM due to data copying
Multi-dimensional arrays can only resize the last dimension
Memory usage may be higher during resize operation

REDIM_SHARED.purpose: Resize shared arrays that are accessible across procedures
behavior: Creates or resizes a global array accessible from all procedures
Combines REDIM functionality with SHARED scoping
Can be called from within SUB/FUNCTION procedures
Affects the global array, not a local copy
use_cases: Resizing global arrays from within procedures
Creating dynamic global arrays at runtime
Managing shared data structures that change size

UBOUND.purpose: Returns the upper boundary (maximum index) of an array dimension
behavior: Returns highest valid index for the dimension
Works with both static and dynamic arrays
First dimension is 1, second is 2, etc.
Essential for safe array iteration
examples: FOR i = 0 TO UBOUND(myArray): PRINT myArray(i): NEXT

LBOUND.purpose: Returns the lower boundary (minimum index) of an array dimension
behavior: Returns lowest valid index for the dimension
Usually 0 for QB64PE arrays (unless using TO keyword)
Works with both static and dynamic arrays
Important for arrays with custom lower bounds
examples: FOR i = LBOUND(myArray) TO UBOUND(myArray): PRINT myArray(i): NEXT

multi_dimensional_arrays.description: Working with multi-dimensional dynamic arrays and boundary functions
code: DIM SHARED mapWidth AS INTEGER, mapHeight AS INTEGER

' Create a new game map with specified dimensions

SUB ResizeMap(newWidth AS INTEGER, newHeight AS INTEGER)

boolean_constants.title: Boolean Values in QB64PE

reserved_words._FALSE: 0 (all bits set to 0) - ALWAYS available as reserved word

user_defined.note: TRUE and FALSE are NOT built-in, but you can define them

boolean_constants.rationale: QB64PE provides _TRUE and _FALSE as reserved words. Traditional TRUE/FALSE are not built-in but can be user-defined. The value -1 represents true (all bits 1) and 0 represents false.
